The problem with automating taxonomy with DNA comparisons is that different genes are expressed differently. For example, the vast majority of human DNA is junk DNA that is not expressed at all. It's totally unused filler data, like the portion of your hard drive that doesn't have anything saved on it, but it has the storage hardware anyway. Somehow, this DNA comparison would need to simulate gene expression to identify the significance of each gene in determining similarity. This is something we are nowhere near being able to accomplish.

Systematics is another branch for the study of the diverse relationships among living things over time. It uses cladistic methods to construct the phylogeny looking at shared traits and the original state of the character. They have an entirely different collection of methods to construct the path through the ranks or phylogeny. They draw branching cladograms.

Taxonomy is the branch involved in identifying, describing and then naming organisms based on their present anatomical differences, no genetic or fossil evidence. This is now used in conjunction with systematics that employs genetic and fossil, if any exist, comparisons and is concerned with relationships through time.

I don't think taxonomy is so much intended for *understanding*, but was instead developed as a method of SORTING.  When you have a highly complex group of things you need to sort, you have to start somewhere, breaking things down.  If your sorting has already been established, and another chunk of items is added, or new things are discovered about what you already have, it's pretty common for your sorting tree to become "unbalanced".  You either live with it, or "balance" the tree.  Rebalancing the tree is probably the most efficient approach, but messes with anything else that's already using the tree.  And that's basically what we have going on right now with taxonomy.  The tree is unbalanced and needs some serious rebalancing, but it's going to be a headache for those that have already used it.

There are many factors that are conspiring to make the science of taxonomy time-pressured, but climate change is not one of them. I wonder why we are still talking about Latin as the language of taxonomy. For instance, the common cat named Felis catus might have a Latin looking name, but while Felis actually is Latin, catus is not. It's just the English "cat" .(or the Swedish "katt") suffixed by -us to look Latin. Yes, Linnaeus already was cheating when naming species. We have the cases of Zingel zingel and Zingel streber. Zingel is the Swedish name for the fish, and Linnaeus just named it Zingel zingel, apparently unable to find a Latin equivalent, as ancient Roman authors never encountered a zingel. A hundred years later, an Austrian researcher found the streber, a fish in the Danube river, to be closely related, and now it's called Zingel streber. Cases like Denhama aussa (an Australian stick insect) are even worse. Again, an Austrian (not Austr-al-ian) researcher was trying hard to classify the Australian stick insects, and when he finally got the first one right, he was calling out in his Austrian accent: "Den hamma aussa!" ("We got him right!"), and the name stuck.
And who ever thought that the definition of a genus like "lifeforms looking similar to each other and having fertile offspring, which also looks similar" is universal or at least works for the most common lifeforms, never looked at the actual way the Common Dandelion (Taraxacum sect. Ruderalia) creates offspring. Lets put it like this: It's complicated.

Actually, the problem is even bigger and deeper than even this thoughtful video implies.

It has to do with something that Aristotle started, the idea of "categories" and whether or not they "exist".

Socrates is a man. Philip is also a man. This means that there's something about both Phlip and Socrates that is shared, namely "man-ness". Therefore "man" is a category.

Is this merely an abstraction? Or is it "real"? Does it have a "real" existence as in something other than merely an idea we have about something?

If it's just an idea, and if "categories" are nothing but abstractions or mere ideas, then modern biology can only be an "idea based on just ideas", which means that it can only have a tenuous link to "real life" as experienced, like pure mathematics.

But if categories are " real" then they should be fairly easy to describe, but, as the video demonstrates, they're not.

So, where does this leave us? I'd like to think that biology has a better relationship with experienced reality than pure math, but there's the thorny problem of categories.

You're forgetting that mammals are also reptiles. "Scientists" will tell you that early amniotes split into synapsids which led to mammals and diapsids which led to "reptiles". However, synapsids, as traditionally defined using skull structure, are paraphyletic with respect to diapsids. Synapsids have an opening in the skull to allow space for jaw muscles. Diapsids have this opening as well, and another one behind it. Furthermore, even when the amniotes split into diapsids and Eupelycosaurs (corresponding to largest clade including mammals but not diapsids), the early Eupelycosaurs had all the traits that would make them reptiles. Those traits were only replaced with different ones (hair/fur instead of scales for example) later on in the Triassic (~230Mya). People used to refer to early Eupelycosaurs as mammal like reptiles, but this term has fallen out of favor because it is perceived as misleading. It is absolutely correct, and definitely better than "stem-mammals" because that doesn't include actual mammals or their direct ancestors.

This was a good episode that was tangible to the laymen.  However, I am disappointed that the word "clade" was not mentioned once.  Ranks aren't just un-scientific--they have been completely rejected by taxonomists for the last several decades, in favor of calling each group a "clade."  Clades are determined by shared derived characteristics, not simply just by what organisms have in common.  One of the most important things for educators to do is teach people about clades, because the idea that organisms are put into classes, etc. is a really widespread misconception.

The video needed some more thorough research. It is quite surprising that the main "problem" mentioned for DNA barcoding-based species description was the lack of resources or accesibility to some researchers/amateurs. Nothing was mentioned about that DNA barcoding, even if useful in countless situations, is conceptually an oversimplification that leads to incorrect species estimation in many cases, particularly when great speciators are involved. DNA barcoding can speed up some species descriptions but, when it fails (hybridization, incomplete lineage sorting, paralogy, radiations, etc.), correcting the failures may take an enormous amount of resources, both in time and funds. There are no shortcuts when describing species, just to have taxonomists working hard and combining all available data, from more classical morphological descriptions to the state-of-the-art molecular techniques.

Eh. Trying to organize everything in clades has some conceptual problems. If amphibians are descended from fish, and reptiles are descended from amphibians, and birds are descended from reptiles, then you kind of wind up with having the top-level group being fish, with amphibians and then reptiles and then birds nested inside of that.

I'm not sure why mammals wouldn't likewise get nested inside of Reptilia.

Likewise, if two subgroups, B and C, of a species A differentiate enough to become two new species, does that make A a new higher level group?

Add cross species interbreeding (wolf-coyote hybrids anybody?) and my head explodes. Perhaps that's the only way to form a sibling clade: if two clades interbreed, are the offspring a new clade directly from the most recent common parent?

Taxonomy is useful for many of the reasons you mentioned and some sort of identification system will always be necessary. However, I'm not sure if traditional taxonomy has a practical value today. The desire to categorize extant species speaks to a preservationist view on the value of the biosphere. While this view is deeply intuitive for a naturalist or someone who has spent a great deal of time in nature, it may not be for the vast majority of people. If we instead look toward understanding how things works, which features and networks lead to ecosystem function and stability, and ultimately reliable and sustainable services for human populations, we may be able to intervene and support environments as they face rapid climate change and other disturbances (if only for our own sake). We could also change the relationship of the average person to the biosphere as something vital to their existence and something in which they participate daily rather than something distant and removed from their lives and livelihood.

Taxonomy is a tool. Tools exist to serve a purpose, which must be identified before the tool is designed and used. Example: Kelvin and Celsius are useful for different purposes. Glossing over the “identify purpose” step invites arbitrary construction, which often causes problems later.

If you rely too much on anatomy or DNA for your taxonomy, convergent evolution will screw it up. If you rely too much on chronology, you end up with the chordata / cnideria problem again because a branch that speciates later but is much more prolific is arbitrarily undervalued.

If the purpose of the taxonomy is to most accurately represent relationships, then I think it would have to capture descent. Pick a definition of “species,” then group according to how many speciation events that branch has had. This would throw out the idea of 8 tiers, but I’m curious to know who decided there always had to be 8 anyway. (E.G. What was the Order of the very first member of Animalia?) This would also result in classifications being accurate to the point of perhaps being unwieldy, or also potentially being fragile because they’d constantly have to update to reflect current understanding. But at that point I’d again have to ask what your goals are. If you prefer ease of use over accuracy, then you should just use common names and Celsius.

Combine approaches?
Work within the tradition for citizen scientists, amateurs, and initial field work - in other words the "old way" serves as the rough-and-ready, "ball park figure" sort of naming. The descriptions would still need to be as thorough and precise as possible. Imaging should be easier than it's ever been, since almost all of us carry around a decent camera in our back pockets, right?
Then, "phase two" would involve those DNA labs, as accumulated samples/descriptions are sent in (or maybe I should say, copies of documentation, samples of actual critters). The labs would have all they could handle (realistically probably way MORE than they could handle, we'd need more labs), BUT: they could work up gene sequence could they not? That no longer takes anywhere near as long (or as much biomass) to manage as it once did. So now you'd have the DNA side, and you could work out that bar code based on that.
THEN, "phase three" would be going back, and comparing the field work and the DNA work. A truly massive database would end up being necessary but we'd be creating that as we worked anyway. All of this obviously hinges on a certain level of basic tech and connectivity...and I do get it that there are still plenty of places on Earth that have neither. But if we really wanted to do it, we could extend ourselves into those areas enough for at least survey missions, couldn't we?

I have a few problems with your assumptions.

I'm not convinced that we should expect phyla to be "equivalent" in terms of diversity. First, remember that phyla are, in some fundamental ways, arbitrary. The entire concept was devised, not to reflect evolution, but rather to organize our thinking on biology. As such, there's no reason to assume that they have anything to do with evolution; evolutionary thought is grafted onto taxonomy, often surprisingly crudely. Many (most?) phyla were developed prior to paleontology being firmly established, and reflect the modern world, NOT the history of life. Second, there is no reason to assume that phyla SHOULD have the same amount of diversity. However we define phyla, there's a good chance that the amount of genetic diversity within them is significant. I don't know of anyone who uses the ability of a taxon to diversify as a character, but it's one that may very well be a significant one--ammonites and forams both show a surprising amount of diversity, while some taxa seem to remain stagnant for a very long time.

Personally I like the idea of defining phyla by focusing on bauplans, but that has flaws as well. Arthropoda is often argued to be a polyphyletic group, because "segmented thing with a shell" is a pretty easy bauplan to evolve, and there are significant differences between members of Arthropoda which suggest different origins.

I also note that you don't get into the more significant problems. For example: there are multiple definitions of "species". How do you define species if the clade you're working with reproduces asexually? Can't use genetic isolation! There's also the assumption that species are genetically isolated from one another, which turns out not to be the case--hybridization can occur in many organisms, and horizontal gene transfer (such as between parasite and host) is also common. And what do you do with a chronospecies, such as bison? Or bacteria, which can exchange genetic information almost at will? The reality is that the biological species concept, which is what taxonomy was based on and which most phylogenetic and cladistic studies assume, only works (sort of) with a limited range of sexually reproducing animals. Genetics? Okay--which genes? Because no one uses the entire genome. Plus you miss out on the vast majority of biological history, since genetic information is not preserved for long in the fossil record. Morphology? That's the de facto default, but five minutes' thought demonstrates the flaws therein.


For my part, I think we need to embrace the fact that biology is messy. It's not going to be neat and orderly like physics or chemistry; biology is a series of exceptions with just enough rules to keep it from completely falling apart. Attempting to redefine the rules to minimize the exceptions misses a very fundamental point about biology: it adapts, constantly, and at all levels, from individual proteins to entire ecosystems.

Taxonomy is challenging since the relationships first described didn't have anything to do with ancestry but merely with morphology/function. Ancestry has long been a contested question. It will always be challenging to impose a Darwinistic outlook onto that structure. Issues abound: fertility, genetic, morphological, and geographical methods of defining relationships all tend to render different shaped trees. Then there is the issue that convergence isn't merely morphological but also genetic: you can't simply assume relatedness because of similar genes or shape/function.


Taxonomy will always be a human imposition onto the world: the content of which will never be unquestionable. But doesn't mean we shouldn't try. Most of the important yet unanswerable questions in life are vital precisely because of the information we gain in the search for a better purchase toward a solution.

If you look at the taxonomy of language, what's clearly wrong, is the way branches like germanic, italic and hellenic are depicted as separate whereas in fact languages within these branches contain links other branches. Molecular taxonomy is priceless, but overestimated for systematics on the large scale. Paraphyletic morphological taxa should exist. If some two groups of jellyfishes so ancient that are more different genetically than humans and some worms, still all their ancestors were jellyfishes, it's relatively conservative groups with "slow" evolution and it is fine to keep it in the same rank as some other phyla that evolved more intensively, but have not enough time to change so much genetically. Main purpose of systematics is to made work with biodiversity more sufficient. Molecular methods great to find polyphyly or some hidden close relations, but if to made a system only by genetic differences ignoring morphology (like 95% differences, 90% differences, etc) - it will be unusable for practical purposes. Molecular taxonomy should be fixing morphological, not replacing it. There are some scientists, mostly geneticists, who telling that we don't need morphology as we can sequence DNA now - hate those guys, so wrong.
